questions.question_text: Name the structure labelled A.
questions.context_text: Escherichia coli is a bacterium that is used widely in scientific experiments and in biotechnology.
questions.image_description: Transmission electron micrograph of E. coli

questions.question_text: Based on your knowledge, estimate the diameter of the E. coli cell. Give your answer in μm.
questions.context_text: Escherichia coli is a bacterium that is used widely in scientific experiments and in biotechnology.
questions.image_description: Transmission electron micrograph of E. coli

questions.question_text: Describe two improvements to the student's method, other than using different equipment, that could improve the accuracy of their population estimate.
questions.context_text: A student carries out a serial dilution of an E. coli culture.

questions.question_text: Calculate the total number of E. coli cells in the original 50cm³ culture. Give your answer in standard form.
questions.context_text: A student carries out a serial dilution of an E. coli culture.

questions.question_text: State two other reasons why E. coli is a suitable microorganism to use in biotechnology.
questions.context_text: E. coli can be genetically modified to produce useful proteins.

questions.question_text: Describe two improvements to the student’s plan and explain why they would be improvements.
questions.context_text: Species biodiversity is affected by many factors. A student plans to sample the plant species in the area shown below to assess the area’s species biodiversity.
questions.image_description: Diagram showing grassland with shrubs, bushes, and a river

questions.question_text: Outline the differences between the bird and mammal results shown in the graph.
questions.context_text: The International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) compiles a list of species and their conservation status, known as the Red List of Threatened Species.
questions.image_description: Bar graph showing threat categories for birds vs mammals

questions.question_text: Evaluate this conclusion.
questions.context_text: A student looking at the graph concluded that ‘climate change is not a major threat to species biodiversity’.
questions.image_description: Bar graph showing threat categories for birds vs mammals

questions.question_text: Describe one way in which timber can be produced sustainably.
questions.context_text: Timber can be produced sustainably to maintain biodiversity in woodland.

questions.question_text: Complete the sentences using the most appropriate words or phrases.
questions.context_text: Xylem vessels maintain the transpiration stream by transporting water up plant stems. The sentences describe the role of meristems in producing xylem vessels.

questions.question_text: State and explain one safety precaution that the students should take when dissecting the vascular tissue.
questions.context_text: A pair of students dissect the vascular tissue of the primrose plant, Primula vulgaris.

questions.question_text: Calculate the actual diameter of the vascular bundle labelled V. Give your answer in mm and to 2 significant figures.
questions.context_text: This is a light micrograph of a transverse section through the stem of P. vulgaris.
questions.image_description: Light micrograph of a transverse section through the stem of P. vulgaris

questions.question_text: Calculate the rate of transpiration, in mm³h⁻¹, during this preliminary trial.
questions.context_text: A scientist plans to investigate the effect of temperature on the rate of transpiration in P. vulgaris. The scientist uses a potometer in their investigation, as shown in the diagram below.

questions.question_text: Describe how the scientist could use the potometer to collect the data needed to assess the effect of temperature on the rate of transpiration in P. vulgaris.
questions.context_text: A scientist plans to investigate the effect of temperature on the rate of transpiration in P. vulgaris.

questions.question_text: State and explain how the leaf of E. cinerea is adapted to limit water loss by transpiration.
questions.context_text: Many plants, such as Erica cinerea (bell heather), have evolved adaptations to limit water loss by transpiration.
questions.image_description: Drawing of a leaf of E. cinerea

questions.question_text: Draw two circles on the diagram around the two parts of the molecule that bond to phosphate when phosphodiester bonds form in DNA.
questions.context_text: Respiration allows cells to carry out processes such as DNA replication.
questions.image_description: Diagram showing a molecule of deoxyguanosine

questions.question_text: Outline why cellular respiration is necessary in cells that are carrying out DNA replication.
questions.context_text: Respiration allows cells to carry out processes such as DNA replication.

questions.question_text: Explain what is likely to happen to the pH of the solution when light is shone on the chloroplasts.
questions.context_text: Chemiosmosis is a mechanism that is thought to occur in both respiration and photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Explain what you would expect to observe in solution 2 and solution 3 after the transfer of the thylakoids.
questions.context_text: André Jagendorf provided evidence for chemiosmosis in an experiment carried out in the 1960s.

questions.question_text: Explain what conclusions can be drawn from the data in the table about the influence of the environment and genetics on the probability of developing diabetes.
questions.context_text: Type 1 diabetes mellitus is characterised by a lack of insulin production. Type 2 diabetes mellitus can involve reduced production of insulin and a decreased response to insulin.
questions.image_description: Table showing percentage probability of both individuals in a pair of twins having the disease

questions.question_text: Identify the structures labelled A, B and C.
questions.context_text: Insulin is secreted from cells in the pancreas.

questions.question_text: Plot the data from the table on the graph and draw a line of best fit.
questions.context_text: The graph shows the changes in the rate of insulin secretion in a person with type 2 diabetes after consuming glucose.
questions.image_description: Graph and table showing changes in insulin secretion

questions.question_text: Complete the table by stating the level of protein structure (primary, secondary, tertiary or quaternary) to which the statement relates.
questions.context_text: The table lists statements about a molecule of insulin.
questions.image_description: Table of statements and protein structure levels

questions.question_text: State how a plasmid containing the gene coding for insulin can be transferred into a bacterial cell.
questions.context_text: Bacteria can be genetically modified to produce insulin.

questions.question_text: Suggest how bacterial cells can be screened to check if they have taken up a recombinant plasmid.
questions.context_text: Bacteria can be genetically modified to produce insulin.

questions.question_text: State a feature of stem cells that allows them to be used to produce pancreatic β-cells.
questions.context_text: In the future, type 1 diabetes could be treated by giving patients new pancreatic β-cells that have been produced in a laboratory from stem cells.

questions.question_text: Explain why patients receiving these new β-cells would still need to be given immunosuppressant drugs.
questions.context_text: In the future, type 1 diabetes could be treated by giving patients new pancreatic β-cells that have been produced in a laboratory from stem cells.

questions.question_text: Describe how artificial clones of plants are produced using micropropagation.
questions.context_text: Plants can be cloned and propagated in horticulture and agriculture.

questions.question_text: State one disease that can infect potato plants and state the type of pathogen that causes the disease.
questions.context_text: Potato plants can be naturally cloned from tubers. Many diseases can infect potato plants.
